item.description:
We think today about progress, and about how much society has advanced in the last few decades technologically, but the evidence for this could equally well be used to argue that these are times of extreme decadence and narcissism. We also bear witness to the barrage of man-made problems, such as climate-change induced storms, gun violence, unstable geo-political territories, and ineffectual stalemated governments with enormous fiscal problems.

How can our view change if we open up the context to progress? If we see the trends of civilization over deep time verses the last several decades?  Or what standard do we use to measure progress?  Is this standard evolving, and can it be seen from different and higher perspectives?

Tonight, we will watch a video from Jeff Salzman at the recent What Next Integral conference. Jeff talks about our worldly concerns, and also opens up the vantage point to where we can see a different trajectory than our ordinary self is accustomed to embodying. We will follow up the video with a group discussion.  All perspectives are welcome, while an open mind is essential.
item.name: A Case for Progress
